texts.shortText: Forms an orange coating between the spiral ridges of shells only of the Scaly dogwhelk Nucella squamosa. The feeding polyps are orange to creamy and each have 5-12 tentacles with longer and shorter tentacles alternating. Between these are both smooth, hollow spines up to 1 mm tall and reproductive individuals (gonozooids), which are shorter with 3-5 very short tentacles and each bearing several round sporosacs.
Polyps up to 4 mm, colonies several cm across, completely covering host shells.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to False Bay.

Easily recognized by its obligate association with the Scaly Dogwhelk and assumed to provide protection to the host by repelling predators. In turn, the hydroid benefits by being transported to new, favourable habitats and by avoiding siltation.
Not studied, but presumed to feed on small particles and planktonic organisms in the water surrounding the host shell, perhaps also particles released by the feeding activities of the host.

Male and female reproductive individuals (gonozooids) borne on different colonies. Male sporosacs are spherical and up to 0.4 mm in diameter and divided into 4 internal compartments. Female sporosacs oval, up to 0.5 mm and each bearing about 32 eggs in 4 tiers.

Easily identified by its obligate host, but several other hydroid species are also found on the surfaces of other gastropod shells, for example H. kaffraria on the estuarine Tick shell Nassarius kraussianus and H. marsupialis on the Purple-lipped dogwhelk Nassarius speciosus.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 52).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to Marine Life on South African Shores. A.A. Balkema, Cape Town (p. 25).

Jones, G (2008). A Field Guide to the Marine Animals of the Cape Peninsula. SURG, Cape Town (p. 58).

Millard, NAH (1975). Monograph on the Hydroida of Southern Africa. Annals of the South African Museum, 68, 1-513 (p. 108).
